captions.text:
Holler at your boy one time! This
week on Thug Notes we gettin twisted with
The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger.

This book tell the story of Holden
Caulfield, a 16 year white boy who start talkin

bout the events that got his ass slung up
in a mental hospital.

You see, last Christmas, Holden got
kicked out of his prissy private school for

flunking all his classes, cept English! Holla!
So then he drops in on his old teach, Spencer,
who tells him that he gotta get his sh%# together.

Later, Holden rolls up to his crib
where he throws down with his roomie Stradlater,

who be mackin some girl Holden used to holler
at.

After gettin his ass whooped,
Holden peaces out to New York city where he gonna
lay low at the Edmont Hotel.

Now my boy comes clean to the
reader and admit he ain’t never busted his

cherry, even though he say he always been
swimmin in trim. So he decide to get himself
a pro named Sunny and get his freak on.

When Sunny rolls up to his crib,
Holden chokes like a bitch and say he just

wanna talk. Then Sunny try to shake my boy
down for mo cash, but Holden ain’t backin
down and kicks her out.

Next thing you know, Sunny’s pimp
Maurice busts in, bitch slaps Holden, and
jacks dat paper.

So Holden eventually decide he
gonna see his baby sister Phoebe, who axe

him what he wanna be about. Holden say he
see himself in a big field of rye full of

kids, where he be standing at the cliff catchin
any little homies who bout to fall off.

When his folks come home, Holden
slips out to kick it with his old teach Mr.

Antolini. But Holden gotta bail when he thinks
that creepy cat be feelin him up while he sleep

At this point, Holden be bout to
straight lose his sh**, so he decide he gotta

get the hell outta dodge. His sista Phoebe
wanna join up, but he shuts her ass down.

Phoebe gets all amped and tells him to shut
his trap.

So Holden apologizes to Phoebe and
takes her to the zoo where he enjoys watchin
her kick it on the carousel.

At this point, Holden say all he
wanna say. He could talk about how he got

sick and got locked up, but he just ain’t
feeling it.

A true playa might say that Catcher
illustrates how Holden tryin to find stability

and acceptance in a broken society full of
people that always be fakin. But when that

fool come up empty handed, he gotta get real
and buck the system.

Break yo-self for this here symbol,
blood. By turning around his hunting hat,

Holden be tellin us that his values be the
reverse of the rest of society’s. And if

you rollin like a G, you probably noticed
that be the same way baseball catchers wear

their hat, foreshadowing his role as the Catcher
in the Rye.

And unless you peep this quote that
be explaining the title, you be actin a straight phony

On the literal, Holden be saving
kids from fallin off a cliff, but figuratively

he saving them from the all the bent-ass shit
of adulthood. Even though they ain’t nothing

Holden can do to stop the pure world of children
from changing to the fake-ass world of adults,

he gonna buck it for hisself and other little
homies for as long as he can.

So when Holden preachin about the
glass cases up in the Museum, what he really

saying is that he don’t wanna join the ranks
of them fake- ass adults. He wanna freeze

time just like dem plastic playas behind the
glass.

That’s why the only one he can
keep it real with is his baby sister Phoebe.

But that ain’t cuttin it. Holden be
trippin cuz he got a legit desire to search

for beauty in human contact, but just ain’t
finding it in a world of such ugliness. This

what makes Holden one of the loneliest playas
in all of literature. He keeps it real, while
errybody else frontin’.

But as much as Holden be spittin
that righteous talk, he sure as hell ain’t

no prince. Like he say: “I’m the most
terrific liar you ever saw in your life.”

And although he want you to think he hard,
homeboy got a gentle soul. That’s why he

always askin what them ducks in the central
park lake gonna do once the water freezes
over.

So, in the end, this gangsta pays
the price for bein too soft in a world twisted

by deceit: By spendin his days in a psych
ward. Damn.

Yo thanks for checkin in, I’ll
catch you next week my well-read ballas.

title: The Catcher in the Rye - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.author: Haylee312

comments.text:
Book that was revolutionary in its time, but when you read it now, you 
don't know what all the fuss was about, censorship and all that. Good book, 
but like the original Road Warrior, hard to appreciate the bizarreness and 
freshness decades later. Not old enough for Catcher, but I remember 
watching Road Warrior in the early 80's thinking 'WTF is this?' Now every 
apocalyptic movie rips off the Road Warrior, so seeing it now is not the 
same, just like reading angsty first person narratives with 'vulgarity' is 
not too surprising and fresh now﻿
comments.author: Joe Johnson

comments.author: Joe Johnson

comments.text: +Joe Johnson thanks for that mate :)
comments.author: Pump for Lotion

comments.text:
+aklepatzky oh...I don't know if I'm qualified for that...but the style in 
which the book was written was somewhat revolutionary, as was the frankness 
of it. Teen angst, disillusionment, and alienation is well-covered these 
days--we even have angsty and troubled teen werewolves and vampires...but 
I'm pretty sure that in Catchers time[1951], there wasn't much out there 
anything like it.

The book was written in a frank, conversational style that seemed unusual 
back then, concentrating on the feelings and inner thought processes of the 
narrator, the inner world, more than the actual events of the story. [This 
caused many to label the main character as 'too whiny']

This makes it a very personal first person narrative where the author is 
laying it all out.

That's the best I can do. I read the book maybe 25 years ago--maybe in high 
school, I don't remember.

I hope this isn't some weird kind of spoiler in case you aren't done 
reading it, but...

What I do remember is the part toward the end where Holden is walking along 
the street worried about 'disappearing'....when I read a novel, that is 
what I look for or look to feel, the feeling I got in my gut when I read 
that...I can't describe it...just like a relation to the material on a gut 
level

I guess in this case, I could relate to his fears of not being able to come 
back and integrate himself into society in any meaningful way, to 
'disappear' and become nothing and nobody

as far as the time it was written, 1951, people objected to the idea of a 
book representing young people using foul language, rejecting societal 
conventions, wanting to buy prostitutes, etc etc...I think that's why 
people freaked out, was the youth of the character

It's been a long time since I read it, so that's the best I can do for you.
comments.author: Joe Johnson

comments.text:
Not when it's important. 
He tells us about being a liar, being a virgin, how much Allie meant to him 
and his destructive reaction. to Allie's death. 

He doesn't feel like telling us about his family, but that doesn't mean 
he's unreliable. He's constantly criticizing them. And he claims to be in 
good relations because he feels that he is. He's not being ingenuine, he's 
just not realizing his faults. 

He's actually very reliable. He tells the reader the most personal things. 
I doubt he would keep his current location a secret.
comments.author: ruvelf

in good relations with Jane but never calls her, despite wanting to 
multiple times. He's unreliable.

comments.text:
+harley martynec Holden is figuratively Buddha on his quest to eternal 
nirvana. Buddha was a prince (Holden at Pensey), Buddha left his kingdom in 
search of "truth" not "phony" royalty (Holden leaving Pencey), Buddha 
eventually reached a tree that he ate the fruit off of and it made him sick 
(Holden going to NYC), but in Buddha's disillusioned state of being sick he 
was actually on a head trip and saw the world spinning, and everything 
became peaceful, he stayed at that tree for eternity hence the "happy 
Buddha" (Holden going home for Phoebe, watching her on the carousel, 
"finding peace" in that moment, and at the psych ward).

comments.author: Daniel Haagen

comments.text:
It seems to me that this book is all about the irony of being a teenager. 
That awkward age in which you are old enough to participate in the "adult" 
world, but young enough to where you can't understand it. Holden talks 
about how he thinks everyone else is a "phony" and how he will save kids 
from growing up in the "phony" society, but he himself is one of the most 
phony in the book. He talks about how much he hates movies yet watches 
them, he lies about the sex he has had and pussys out, and many other 
things. Holden is what he hates. ﻿

comments.author: Adjoa Baidoo

comments.text:
After just reading the book, I can tell you all the way through Holden is a 
straight up bitch (hard hitting critical analysis). They say sometimes you 
really hate the characters you subconsciously relate to, but I can't stand 
the idea of thinking so rottenly about other people. He's whiny and 
irritable, and always sees the world and the future through the negative 
lens of depression - unable to perceive all the positive things that 
adulthood can bring to people (maybe Salinger didn't, either). ﻿
comments.author: Javjean

comments.text:
OH MY GOD THIS BOOK IS SO RELATABLE. DAMN IT!


Ugh. It turns out Caulfied is a relatable jackass: of several jarring 
similarities there are between him and I, the one that stands most 
invidious is my instant scorn of his snide and snarky judgemental thoughts. 
Whoops. That one speaks for itself in this commentary, but did I mention 
Cauldfield doesn’t have much insight either?

Sickeningly, one of the central ideas of the damn thing is Holden whining 
around NYC – he is loath to assimilate into the ‘phony’ world of adults, he 
wants to stay young and innocent and carefree. To freeze time, like a 
diorama at a museum. He visits the pond he used to ski at when he was a 
child, he goes back to the Natural History Museum, he went to every week as 
a little kid and so on are among the main instances of his desire to turn 
back time. How many times have I – and countless others – retained classic 
childhood stories (Harry Potter and Rolad Dahl, for me) as a reaction to 
the stressors in adult life?
comments.author: Javjean

comments.text:
Really surprising he missed Holden's misinterpretation of the poem "Comin' 
Thro' the Rye," which in some versions has rather sexual overtones!  Holden 
pictures himself as catching children coming through the rye as to stop 
them from adulthood, while the real poem is really about adults doing adult 
things!﻿

comments.text:
Except it IS an interesting books for those who empathize with Holden.

The reason I find people don't like it is because they strongly disagree 
with all of Holden's thoughts and commentary, and that's like 75% of the 
book.

comments.author: www.charlotteannekirby.com

comments.text: You should do The Count of Monte Cristo﻿
comments.author: Spencer Haithcock

comments.text:
I hate when people reduce Holden to this whiny, pretentious character. He 
was more than that. His little brother died when he was a kid and since 
Holden never saw him grow up, he got this obsessive purity thing to other 
kids. And you know what? He was genuinely sad about the world. He looked 
all over the place for someone to tell him it's okay to grow up and believe 
it or not, when you can't find that, life is pretty fucking hard.﻿

comments.text: Quick concise and to the point thanks!﻿

comments.author: Louise Vinciguerra

comments.text:
I actually liked this book...for the exact opposite reason that many do. I 
always wanted to know what the hell spoiled brats who thought they were 
holier than thou were thinking all day long, and lo and behold, Holden 
answered those questions.﻿
comments.author: ZhangtheGreat

comments.text:
I hated reading the book in high school. Reason being, I was a weird 
confused angry kid too, but I didn't think it made me better than anyone 
else. I had a hard time finding common ground with anyone too but I felt 
like "they're all phonies" was an excuse given by Holden so he didn't have 
try anymore.﻿
comments.author: nikoincroatia

comments.text:
You forgot about Allie, his dead little brother. Allie motivates half the 
shit Holden does and his absence is a negative presence in the book. It is 
while holding Allie's baseball mitt that Holden has the vision of being the 
Catcher in the Rye. This was a big thing to leave out. Usually The Thug 
does such a thorough job, leaving out Allie is something that he should not 
be allowed to slack on!﻿
comments.author: Pauline Triage

comments.text:
+nikoincroatia
Then you might want to read the book again, Allie was incredibly important.
comments.author: Proli

comments.text:
Also forgot to mention that Holden says "This isn't the first time 
something like this have happened to me" when getting creeped on by his 
former teacher. That is a pretty subtle hint but have a huge impact on the 
story.
comments.author: ShadY Knight

comments.text:
I agree, the brother was an enormous part of work, his death is pretty much 
the main reason Holden gets so fucked up later in life.
comments.author: futuredirector999

comments.text:
+nikoincroatia
Yep, Holden is holding Allie's baseball mitt when he muses on being the 
Catcher in the Rye. He is torn because he partly feels like he let Allie 
"fall off the cliff" but there is an element of envy to how Holden feels 
about Allie since, as the thug points out, Holden is very unhappy about 
being forced to grow up and join the "phonies" of the adult world, and by 
dying, Allie has managed to cheat destiny in a way Holden can't.
comments.author: Pauline Triage

comments.text: I don't remember a dead brother
comments.author: nikoincroatia

comments.text: I love this guy!﻿
